video.title: Deno Course - Better than Node.js?
video.description:
Learn how to use Deno in this complete course. Deno is a Node.js alternative created by the same person who created Node.js. In this tutorial course, you will learn how to build real apps with Deno. You will also learn the basics of the Typescript. You will see how to use Deno to build a survey app with a REST API using MongoDB.

💻 Code: https://github.com/thecodeholic/freecodecamp-deno-course
💻 Survey application code: https://github.com/thecodeholic/deno-survey

🎥 Course from The Codeholic. Check out his channel: https://www.youtube.com/channel/UC_UMEcP_kF0z4E6KbxCpV1w
🐦 The Codeholic on Twitter: https://twitter.com/TheCodeholic

🔗 Official Deno website: https://deno.land/

⭐️ Course Contents ⭐️
Introduction
---------------------
⌨️ (00:00:00) Introduction
⌨️ (00:02:02) Course overview
⌨️ (00:04:38) Course Project
⌨️ (00:05:51) What is Deno
⌨️ (00:08:19) Course project (Survey app) demo
⌨️ (00:11:54) Install and Getting started
⌨️ (00:14:34) Write "Hello World"
⌨️ (00:15:50) Main Features

TypeScript
---------------------
⌨️ (00:17:22) What is TypeScript
⌨️ (00:24:04) TypeScript Types
⌨️ (00:37:40) Interfaces
⌨️ (00:43:46) Classes
⌨️ (00:48:03) Generics
⌨️ (00:56:31) Enums

Main features
---------------------
⌨️ (01:01:23) Import from URL
⌨️ (01:02:23) ES6 Modules import syntax
⌨️ (01:03:01) Top Level await
⌨️ (01:04:18) Browser API
⌨️ (01:06:20) Security
⌨️ (01:16:31) Single Executable file

⌨️ (01:18:55) Terminal commands
⌨️ (01:23:52) Standard Library and 3rd party modules
⌨️ (01:26:31) Create basic HTTP server
⌨️ (01:32:20) Working with file system
⌨️ (01:41:55) Using npm packages
⌨️ (01:45:40) Answers on common questions

Project - Survey app
----------------------
⌨️ (01:57:02) Install oak framework and setup basic server
⌨️ (02:03:41) Install denon for automatic server restart on file change
⌨️ (02:06:03) Easily manage versions and dependencies
⌨️ (02:08:06) Organize routes
⌨️ (02:09:36) Create AuthController and configure Login & Register routes
⌨️ (02:13:54) Setup connection with MongoDB
⌨️ (02:19:40) Create User model and implement registration
⌨️ (02:40:42) Implement login
⌨️ (02:54:16) Install dontenv and create .env file

Survey CRUD
----------------------
⌨️ (02:59:35) Configure routes for Survey CRUD and Create SurveyController
⌨️ (03:04:52) Create Survey model and implement Survey creation
⌨️ (03:11:22) Implement get surveys
⌨️ (03:20:33) Create BaseModel and inherit Survey and User models from there
⌨️ (03:26:12) Implement to get single survey
⌨️ (03:31:29) Implement survey update
⌨️ (03:39:22) Printing application errors
⌨️ (03:40:26) Fixing problem of "this" binding
⌨️ (03:44:27) Implement survey deletion
⌨️ (03:48:52) Create authMiddleware and add authentication to Survey CRUD

⌨️ (04:07:38) Implement CRUD of questions

Create Website
----------------------
⌨️ (04:44:15) Create SiteController and configure routes
⌨️ (04:47:38) Install template engine and create views
⌨️ (04:51:48) Render all surveys
⌨️ (04:55:32) Configure oak to handle static files (CSS, Javascript, Images)
⌨️ (05:06:05) Write basic styles
⌨️ (05:07:31) Create and use partial view files
⌨️ (05:09:30) Implement to view single survey
⌨️ (05:33:58) Get form submitted data and validation
⌨️ (05:49:07) Implement displaying validation errors in form
⌨️ (06:01:45) Implement to save survey answers
⌨️ (06:14:49) Create a real survey using our survey app



--



Learn to code for free and get a developer job: https://www.freecodecamp.org

Read hundreds of articles on programming: https://freecodecamp.org/news

topLevelComment.author: The Codeholic
topLevelComment.text:
Thanks to FreeCodeCamp for publishing this video and thank you all for watching it.
👇👇Check my YouTube channel for more videos on Deno.👇👇
http://youtube.com/TheCodeholic
And let us know in the comments section what video you want on Deno.

replies.text: Next Tutorial Deno with ReactJS

replies.author: The Codeholic
replies.text:
​@Kadiro Okirim No. I have about 40 minutes section of TypeScript which covers all the necessary things you need to know.
And it will be good to have at least basic understanding of Node.js to compare Deno to it in some cases, but it is not mandatory. 
The only required things are JavaScript and OOP.

topLevelComment.author: Stanko Kostic
topLevelComment.text:
Hello and thank you for this great tutorial! Since I am not that used to TS/JS, and backend development in general, can you explain a bit more why are 'find' and 'prepare' methods in the models static, while 'save'/'update' are not? Is that some general coding pattern that I am not aware of?
Also, why is prepare method returning a new instance of the object, instead of just returning a modified one?

topLevelComment.text: If you have issues connecting with mongo atlas add this to the end of the client.connect (as is the method used in the last mongo driver version not Uri) "&authMechanism=SCRAM-SHA-1" without quotation of course so the connection recognize the new authentication mechanism.

topLevelComment.author: Junior Moreira
kebman
topLevelComment.text: After trying out TypeScript a bit, I must say, it seems a pretty minimal add-on to JavaScript So if you already know JavaScript, this certainly seemed like a breeze to me. Of course, this is just from a small test run. I think it's worth going deeper with it, because of the extra control and fault-resistance it's supposed to give you.

replies.author: Navjot Singh
replies.text: It's a subset of JavaScript, and all JavaScript is valid typescript.

topLevelComment.author: Sergiu
topLevelComment.text:
Use denon in Git bash:
1. Add the file in your PATH(env variablies):
    C:\Users\YourUsername\.deno\bin\denon.cmd
2. Make an alias for 'denon.cmd':
    Run in Git bash or add in bash profile: 'alias denon=denon.cmd'
3. Done.

replies.author: Leonardo Severini
replies.text: Don't use the same variable user  you used for the DB. Create a new one. For example I used "let _user=await User.findOne..." for check the DB, and "let user = new User...".

topLevelComment.author: Ramender Singh
topLevelComment.text: I really don't understand the most touted feature of deno i.e., security (sand box model). My question is who is stopping any user from running any deno application with --allow-all flag. For example, if I am a malicious user I can run deno with --allow-all flag, who is stopping me from doing it. Can anyone please explain.

replies.author: MrAfusensi
replies.text: Users have no control over how a server has their flags set up

topLevelComment.author: Steve Breese
topLevelComment.text: Too avoid crashing the app when the document id is invalid, use findOne({ _id: ObjectId(id) }) instead of findOne({ _id: { $uid: id } }).

topLevelComment.author: Khalid Ali
topLevelComment.text:
Quick question. Some of the typescript errors aren't showing on VS Code. For example, at 45:18, I don't get an error in VS Code for age not initialized. I do get the error when I run on the Terminal though. Did you configure a tsconfig or is there an extension that I am missing?
Another example of this problem is at 54:13 where the code runs fine, but the VS Code gives an error on the 'await' saying awaits are only allowed at the top level of a file.
-
Solved by installing the Denoland extension in VS Code.

replies.author: Ashwin Kumar
replies.text: But why Deno then?

replies.author: The Codeholic
replies.text:
Well said. But there are tools which help you much more then others. So I think that fundamentals of programming are more important than this or that technology, but you still need basic knowledge in order to start building.
For example: If you know Node.js already, it is possible to learn Deno in 6 hours 😉.
But if you don't know OOP or fundamentals of Javascript you should not probably start learning Deno yet.
